problem_text:
A finite set of reductions ui → vi of words on a finite alphabet Σ = Σ−1 is called a group set of reductions if length(ui) > length(vi) or length(ui) = length(vi) and ui > vi in the lexicographical ordering, and every word in Σ can be reduced to the unique reduced form which does not depend on the sequence of reductions. Do there exist group sets of reductions satisfying the condition length(vi) ⩽ 1 for all i, which are different from 1) sets of trivial reductions x−εxε → 1, ε = ±1, 2) multiplication tables xy → z of finite groups, and 3) their finite unions?
Yu. I. Merzlyakov
answer: Yes, there do (J. Avenhaus, K. Madlener, F. Otto, Trans. Amer. Math. Soc., 297 (1986), 427–443).
